overall_score_comment: This reads like a diss track written by a very angry historian who just discovered Google and thinks every metaphor needs a TED Talk.
the_roast:
Let's start with the elephant in the room: Kendrick really said 'call an amberlamps' in 2024 like we're still watching viral videos from 2010. My guy, that meme is so old it has a mortgage and two kids in college. And 'Deebo any rap nigga, he a free throw'? So you're saying your opponents are... easy shots that professionals still somehow miss 25% of the time? That's not the flex you think it is, Kenny.

The whole 'certified pedophiles' section is basically Kendrick screaming 'I HAVE ALLEGATIONS' for sixteen bars straight like a hip-hop Maury Povich episode. 'Say Drake, I hear you like 'em young' followed by 'hide your lil' sister' – we get it, you have one angle and you're going to beat it into the ground like a rented mule. Then there's 'Tryna strike a chord and it's probably A minor' which is admittedly clever until you realize he's so proud of this one pun that he probably workshopped it for three weeks and called his mom to tell her about it.

But nothing – and I mean NOTHING – compares to the trainwreck that is the 'Atlanta is a colonizer' metaphor. Kendrick really looked at a beef with Drake and thought 'You know what this needs? A five-paragraph essay about antebellum railroad construction.' My brother in Christ, this is supposed to be a diss track, not your application to a PhD program in Urban Studies. 'The settlers was usin' townfolk to make 'em richer' – yes, Kendrick, we all took 8th grade social studies. Comparing Drake working with Atlanta rappers to literal slavery and colonization is the kind of reach that would make Mr. Fantastic jealous. You're out here delivering a dissertation when everyone just wanted you to roast the man's ghostwriters.

And can we talk about the repetition? 'They not like us' gets repeated so many times I thought my Spotify was glitching. It's like Kendrick discovered the copy-paste function and decided to build his entire hook around it. Then there's 'freaky-ass nigga, he a 69 God' chanted like a demonic ritual – sir, this isn't an exorcism, it's a diss track. The 'OV-ho' call-and-response at the end sounds like a children's birthday party game that went horribly, horribly wrong. 'Are you my friend? Are we locked in?' – what is this, a therapy session or a rap battle? I half expected him to ask Drake about his feelings and whether he's been drinking enough water.

cliche_counter.quip: Nothing says 'I'm culturally relevant' like referencing viral videos from the Obama administration

cliche_counter.cliche: Comparing yourself to a biblical figure/martyr
cliche_counter.quip: 'Nail a nigga to the cross' – because nothing screams street credibility like messiah complex
Every diss track writer thinks they invented this line, and they're all equally unoriginal
When you write 'they not like us' 47 times, that's not a hook, that's a hostage situation
The only thing getting murdered here is your audience's attention span during your Civil War lecture
Congratulations, you're the 10,000th rapper to make a bird joke about an owl logo – here's your participation trophy

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: call an amberlamps, tell him 'Breathe, bro'
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Mandatory viewing of every viral video from 2010-2015 until you understand they're dead, Jim

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: The settlers was usin' townfolk to make 'em richer / Fast-forward, 2024, you got the same agenda
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: First-Degree Metaphor Murder and Assault with a Deadly Dissertation
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Teaching summer school US History until you learn that diss tracks aren't the place for your academic theories

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: What OVO for? The 'Other Vaginal Option'?
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Aggravated Dad Joke in a No-Dad-Joke Zone
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Listening to every middle school freestyle that did this exact same acronym joke better

lyrical_crime_highlights.quip: Copy-Paste Abuse and Reckless Repetition Causing Public Annoyance
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Writing 'I will diversify my vocabulary' 500 times on a chalkboard

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Are you my friend? Are we locked in?
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Unlawful Breaking of Fourth Wall While Armed with Cringe
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Attending conflict resolution therapy and learning that rap beef shouldn't sound like couples counseling

hidden_meanings: Upon deeper analysis, 'Not Like Us' is clearly Kendrick's cry for help, revealing his secret dream of becoming a tenured professor who assigns pop quizzes about Reconstruction-era economics. The repeated 'they not like us' is actually him trying to convince himself that he's still different from Drake, despite the fact that both of them are wealthy celebrities arguing on tracks that sound increasingly like academic peer review sessions with better production.
final_verdict: This track is what happens when someone gives a brilliant rapper too much time to overthink and access to a history textbook. It's one part diss track, two parts dissertation defense, and three parts that one friend who won't let a joke die – all wrapped up in production so good it almost distracts you from the fact that Kendrick just compared Future collaborating with Drake to actual slavery and expected us to nod along like that made sense.
title: Not Like Us
